.  It is the tip of the "pinky finger" on maps of Michigan, and is known for its scenic coastal beauty, small towns, and winemaking.

value: Empire (pop. 378) — a great base for seeing the Sleeping Bear Dunes
Glen Arbor (pop. 788) — home to the Cherry Republic
Lake Leelanau(pop.359) county jail, county courthouse. Leelanau Enterprise Paper. Walleye Festival in May.
(pop. 648) — the northernmost town, at the tip of the peninsula, with convenient lighthouse access. State campground next to lighthouse grounds.
Suttons Bay (pop. 589) — a charming town with good shops, restaurants and wineries. Counties' only movie theater.
Cedar — home to the Cedar Polka Festival
— home to historic Fishtown and the Manitou Island ferry. The county seat.
Omena has a small cove of Lake Michigan.
Peshawbestown — home to the Leelanau Sands Casino and the Peshawbestown Pow-Wow held in August.

The main road into the peninsula is MI-22, which basically hugs the western shoreline from
through Leland up to Northport, then turns south and follows the eastern shoreline through Suttons Bay to

value: . Operates 6:10AM to 6:40PM M-F, and 8:10AM to 5:40PM on Saturday; no service on Sundays. Fixed-route service within Traverse City, and an advance-reservation curb-to-curb service in rural Leelanau and Grand Traverse counties. Fares $1.

content=In Leland is one of the few remaining commercial fishing complexes on the Great Lakes, made up of shanties, fish tugs and docks, dating back to around 1853. Locals are justifiably proud of it, and have been working hard to keep it preserved.

, Leelanau State Park off M-20 in Northport, 231-386-7195 or 231-922-5270,

. Hours vary by season. Restored 1858 lighthouse resembling a keeper's home of the 1920s and 30s. Also has information on the South Fox Island Lighthouse. Located at the tip of the Leelanau Peninsula. Admission $2.

:*
. Built in 1867, now obsolete and located on a privately-owned island with no currently-available public access.

value: content=In Leland. Open 10AM to 4PM W-Sa (winter). Features exhibits reflecting the cultural history of the Leelanau Peninsula and its islands from the time of first human habitation.
content=In Greilickville. Exhibits on water, fishing, the weather, lighthouses, art and more.

content=In Peshawbestown, 231-534-8100 or 800-922-2WIN. Open 12PM to 2AM M-F, and 10AM to 2AM Saturday and Sunday. Card games, slot machines, bingo hall. On-site restaurant called the Double Eagle Grill, and Sand Dollar bar. Entertainment showroom with nationally recognized entertainers.
The Leelanau Peninsula has a number of lakes, two of the largest being Glen Lake, south of Glen Arbor by

, and North and South Lake Leelanau, which stretch 13 miles south from Leland through the center of the county, with the town of Lake Leelanau located between the north and south branches. The lakes make for some beautiful photo opportunities, particularly the views of Glen Lake from the tall sand dunes.

Visitors may wish to embark upon a

of the Leelanau Peninsula. With thirteen of them in the county, it's probably inadvisable to do all of them in one day, but you could break this trip up with relative ease. Driving the whole trip straight would only take about 2 hours, but of course you'll want to stop along the way!

, 4600 S Country Club Drive in Cedar, 888-228-0121,

. 18 holes, par 70. Designed and built by Arnold Palmer and Palmer Design Course Company. Full-service golf shop, on-site Steak-Haus restaurant and bar. $15 - $80.

:*
, Otto Road in Suttons Bay, 231-271-2020 or 877-533-5262,

. 18 championship holes, par 71. Pro shop, clubhouse, spacious practice facility. Private lessons and golf clinics. $39 - $69.

:*There is also the private and exclusive Leland Country Club on the Lake Leelanau shore in Leland.

. Held one day in late July. Afternoon and evening lineup of classic jazz, plus the finest wines and food from Leelanau County. Admission $25 in advance, $35 at the gate.

Suttons Bay Art Festival, Marina Park in Suttons Bay. Held the first full weekend in August. Jurried art show. Food tent vendors.

Leland Wine Festival. Leland Marina. Wine and food vendor tent.

Lake Leelanau Walleye Festival, May. Events such as queen crowing, and fishing contests.

Tour De' Tart. Family bike ride every summer. To showcase the TART and raise funds.

M-22 Triathalon. Held in the Glen Arbor area in mid-june.

Christmas in the Village. Downtown Suttons Bay. Mid-December. Carolers, tree lighting, shopping bargins.

Cedar Polka Festival. Cedar. First week in July. Dancing. Polka Mass.

Northport Lighthouse Days. Grand Traverse Lighthouse, Northport.

value: content=In Glen Arbor. Dried cherries, chocolate cherries, cherry nut mixes, cherry jams and jellies, sauces and toppings, cherry salsa, barbecue and dressings, cherry baked goods, cherry candies, cherry juice and concentrate, cherry beverages and soda pop, cherry wines, clothing, cherry bath and home accessories. Antique soda fountain, cherry bakery and light lunches including sandwiches and salads with a cherry twist.
content=Local, organic and world foods. Owned by Phil.
, Cedar. Family owned and ran. Products made in store. Perogi.
content=Open 7AM to 3PM daily. All-day breakfasts, salads, sandwiches and burgers. Try their homemade soups. $3 - $7.50.
content=In Leland, 231-256-9971 or 888-257-0102. Open 5 to 9PM daily, and 10AM to 2PM on Sunday. Meat and seafood entrees with European flair. Try the Michigan ostrich. $20 - $30.
content=In Suttons Bay. Scratch cooking with local ingredients. Try the sautéed morel mushroom duxelles ravioli in morel cream sauce and the buffalo meatloaf.
content=Exquisite fine dining on Lake Michigan, open year-round with seasonal hours of operation.
content=Cute outdoor grill in the parking lot of the Northport marina.  Burgers, hot dogs, gyros, egg rolls,hummus, and more.  Open weekdays for lunch, weather permitting.

There are thirteen wineries located in the Leelanau Peninsula. If that's still not enough for you, you can check out the five other wineries on the Old Mission Peninsula, north of
, 6530 S Lake Shore Drive in Cedar, 231-228-4800,

. Open 11AM to 6PM Monday through Saturday, and 12PM to 6PM on Sunday. 18 white, red, sparkling, dessert and cherry wines.

, 10844 E Revold Road in Suttons Bay, 231-271-4970 or 231-271-4882 ext 130,

. Open 11AM to 6PM Monday through Saturday, and 12PM to 5PM on Sunday. 20 white, red, sparkling, fruit, dessert and ice wines, hard apple cider, and 7 fruit spirits. Also home to the Leelanau Cheese Company, producers of Raclette cow's-milk cheese and fromage blanc cheese spread. Wine tastings are $5 for 5 samples (plus an engraved tasting glass to keep; if you bring it with you on subsequent visits, your tastings are free), or $5 for 2 samples from their reserve list of spirits; Raclette samples are $1.
